item.title: Throwback: The Malware Historian
item.description:
Today malware is all nation state actors and organized crime, but in the beginning it was more about making a statement. Dan is a malware historian. He finds old hardware and viruses, runs them, and sees what happens. So we sat down to discuss the history of malware, where it's come from, and where he thinks it's going next.
Check out his amazing YouTube channel at â https://www.youtube.com/user/danooct1
Hacked is brought to you by PushSecurity.com. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: The 4chan Hack
item.description:
We discuss a schism years in the making â€” the infamous imageboard 4chan gets hacked by its own offshoot, Soyjak.party, in a breach that exposed moderator identities, source code, and shattered the myth of online anonymity. Then, we look at Cluely â€” an AI tool built by a suspended student to help users â€œcheatâ€ on job interviews â€” and the viral campaign pitching it as a revolution. Is it a tech breakthrough, a social bluff, or both?

item.title: WebcamGate
item.description:
In 2009, a Pennsylvania high school accused sophomore Blake Robbins of dealing drugsâ€”based on a photo secretly taken through his school-issued laptop. The image, captured without his knowledge in his own bedroom, turned out to show candy. But the real story wasnâ€™t about what was in his handâ€”it was about how the school got the photo in the first place. In this episode, we speak with filmmaker Jody McVeigh-Schultz, creator ofÂ SPY HIGH, and Blake himself, about surveillance, bias, and what happens when institutions cross the line between protecting kids and controlling them.

item.title: The Killswitch Saboteur, AI Prompt Data Leak, and Bluetooth Chip Secrets Exposed
item.description:
A former developer at Eaton Corp, Davis Lu, is convicted of deploying a kill switch script that disrupted thousands of users worldwideâ€”heâ€™s now facing up to 10 years in prison. A major AI image generator, GenNomis, accidentally exposed 95,000 image prompts online, raising serious privacy and security concerns. And finally, researchers discover debug commands in the popular ESP32 Bluetooth chip, sparking worries about potential exploitation.

item.title: Hacking Security Camera AI
item.description: Can you trick the AI model running locally on a security camera into thinking you're a bird (and not a burglar)? We sat down Kasimir Schulz, principle security researcher at HiddenLayer, to discuss Edge AI, and to learn about how AI running on your device (at the "edge" of the network) can be compromised with something like a QR code.
